div.title: The Princeton Dictionary of Buddhism defines and explains dhāraṇī:1

q.p: In Sanskrit “mnemonic device,” “code.” The term is derived etymologically from the Sanskrit root √dhṛ (“to hold” or “to maintain”), thus suggesting something that supports, holds, or retains; hence, a verbal formula believed to “retain” or “encapsulate” the meaning of lengthier texts and prolix doctrines, thus functioning as a mnemonic device. It is said that those who memorize these formulae (which may or may not have semantic meaning) gain the power to retain the fuller teachings that the dhāraṇī “retain.” Commenting on the Bodhisattvabhūmisūtra [sic], Buddhist exegetes, such as the sixth-century Chinese scholiast Jinying Huiyuan, describe dhāraṇī as part of the equipment or accumulation (saṃbhāra) that bodhisattvas need to reach full enlightenment, and classify dhāraṇī into four categories, i.e., those associated with (1) teachings (dharma), (2) meaning (artha), (3) spells (mantra) and (4) acquiescence (kṣānti). The first two types are involved with learning and remembering the teachings and intent of Buddhist doctrine and thus function as “codes.” . . . The third type (mantradhāraṇī) helps the bodhisattva to overcome adversity, counter baleful influences, and bestow protection. . . . The fourth type assists the bodhisattva in acquiescing to the true nature of dharmas as unproduced . . . , giving him the courage to remain in the world for all sentient beings.

div.p: This informative dictionary entry ends by helpfully describing the various occurrences of dhāraṇī and suggesting that they are probably not to be considered proto-tantric texts (contrary to one prevailing theory) but rather belong to a pan-Buddhist context. However, the Indian Buddhist locus classicus for a fourfold division of dhāraṇīs is not a sūtra, as stated by that dictionary, but rather a treatise entitled the Bodhisattvabhūmi. The relevant passage was also discussed and translated by Jens Braarvig,See Braarvig 1985, p. 19–20: “The Bodhisattvabhūmi divides dhāraṇī into four types: dharmadhāraṇī of Dharma], [arthadhāraṇī of the meaning], [mantradhāraṇī of mantras] and [dhāraṇī to attain the tolerance, kṣānti, of a bodhisattva. By the first type the bodhisattva acquires the power of remembrance (smṛti) and insight (prajñā) into the Dharma, and thus is able to retain in memory for endless time any book merely by hearing it once. Arthadhāraṇī is the same, only here one retains the meaning of the book, not just the words, as in the first. . . . The third, mantradhāraṇī, at first seems to justify the translation ‘magical formula.’ Here, the bodhisattva acquires the power of concentration, samādhivaśitā, and he employs the mantras magically to alleviate the sufferings of living beings . . . the fourth, the bodhisattvakṣāntilabhāya dhāraṇī dhāraṇī for attaining the bodhisattva’s tolerance][ . . . consists in pondering a mantra until one understands its meaning, namely that it is without meaning, and accordingly understands all dharmas as being beyond expression. The bodhisattva’s kṣānti is the tolerance of this state of things, that dharmas are unborn, empty and so on.” who renders this fourfold classification of dhāraṇī as (1) dhāraṇī of Dharma, (2) dhāraṇī of the meaning, (3) dhāraṇī of mantras, and (4) dhāraṇī to attain tolerance. Braarvig also cites the Akṣaya­matinirdeśa, which characterizes dhāraṇī as both remembrance itself and the faculty or means of retaining in memory the teachings of the buddhas.Braarvig 1985, p. 18. Braarvig thus observes that dhāraṇī became connected with concentration (samādhi), remembrance or recollection (smṛti), and meditation (dhyāna), concluding that “dhāraṇī and samādhi naturally belong together; to retain something in memory, concentration is needed, and remembrance may produce concentration.” Braarvig 1985, p. 22.

It should be noted that J. S. Negi in his dictionary entry for the phrase don gyi gzungs (dhāraṇī of the sense) quotes the same fourfold enumeration of dhāraṇī from the Bodhisattvabhūmi.See J. S. Negi 1993–2005, vol. 6, p. 2318: (1) dhāraṇī of the Dharma (chos kyi gzungs, dharmadhāraṇī), (2) dhāraṇī of the sense (don gyi gzungs, arthadhāraṇī), (3) dhāraṇī of mantras (gsang sngags kyi gzungs, mantradhāraṇī), and (4) bodhisattva’s dhāraṇī for gaining of forbearance, (byang chub sems dpa’ bzod pa ’thob par byed pa’i gzungs, bodhisattvakṣāntidhāraṇī). In a standard modern Tibetan–Chinese dictionary, moreover, the same four gzungs kyi sgo (access to the dhāraṇī) appear, but in a different order, while the third one is called tshig gi gzungs (dhāraṇī of words), instead of chos kyi gzungs (dhāraṇī of Dharma).See Krang Dbyi-sun 1985, p. 2506.

The topic of dhāraṇī has also received notable attention from Janet Gyatso, who provides a rich semiotic analysis focusing on the work of the Tibetan author Dodrupchen Jikten Tenpai NyimaThis is the phonetic rendering of the Tibetan name rdo grub chen ’jigs med bstan pa’i nyi ma. (1865–c. 1926). Drawing on the theories of Charles Sanders Peirce, Gyatso argues that dhāraṇī function as “iconic signifiers” that represent their signified objects by virtue of being similar to them.See Gyatso 1992, p. 179. Noting common examples of iconic signifiers such as pictures, diagrams, and metaphors, she argues that dhāraṇīs are analogous to these since—following the explanation of Dodrupchen—their lack of any conventional meaning is in fact their meaning: “Again, as the mantric formula itself has no linguistically expressible meaning, it resembles the thusness that it is signifying, and so it can be employed as an iconic sign.”Gyatso 1992, p. 191. Here the idea is that dhāraṇī qua iconic signs can free practitioners from their own deluded conventions, functioning as “reminders” of inexpressible emptiness. The assumption is that deluded sentient beings forget the “profound situation” of emptiness, and gradually may become accustomed to indexical and symbolic signs that come to be understood as “icons of that birthless truth.” Gyatso 1992, p. 195.

Ronald DavidsonOn the different meanings of dhāraṇī and the Western scholarly reception of the term, see Davidson 2009. argues that dhāraṇī are “codings” for different elements of Buddhist tradition including doctrines, syllables, scriptures, ritual powers, the elimination of negative karma, the destruction of unwholesome psychological states, essential elements of the Buddhist path, and even the path in its entirety. In this regard, he criticizes his predecessors for limiting their analyses of dhāraṇī to intellective and mnemonic functions.Davidson 2009, p. 106. He also recognizes dhāraṇī as a scriptural genre, describing it as an extremely diverse phenomenon:

q.p: Dhāraṇīs are phrases/statements/texts that operate in the same manner as dhāraṇīs as syllables/letters or as mantras, from coding elements of doctrine to the entire canon to acting as a vehicle for final liberation. This function yields dhāraṇīs as a genre, which often includes prayers, aspirations, ritual programs and concluding summaries of benefits. It is indicative, though, that texts in the genre can have their mantradhāraṇīs abstracted elsewhere with no sense that there is a loss of the meaning, just what we might expect for coded information.[](note id:UT22084-057-004-24)

div.p: Davidson prefaces these characterizations of dhāraṇī by cautioning that the volume and proliferation of dhāraṇī scriptures and dhāraṇī-related rites necessitate that any statement concerning dhāraṇīs “requires qualification almost before it is written.”Davidson 2009, p. 141. He notes that this situation is exacerbated by the fact that Mahāyāna sūtras “sometimes contradict each other and, occasionally, themselves.”Davidson 2009, p. 141.

In his second article on dhāraṇī, Davidson takes a different approach, using the linguistic tools of historical pragmatics. Drawing on the work of John Searle, Davidson explores how dhāraṇī texts might be fruitfully analyzed as consisting of illocutionary acts. He finds nine forms of such acts in his sources: (1) precipitating assertives that articulate a problem condition or a miraculous event, (2) directives to speak or perform the dhāraṇī, with the verb in the imperative or optative, (3) commissive statements promising to communicate a dhāraṇī, (4) assertives in the forms of precedent or predictive statements extolling the use of the given dhāraṇī by a/some/many previous buddhas, (5) assertives as benefit statements that usually concern the dhāraṇī’s power to ward off disease, poison, possession, or enemies, or that affirm health, welfare, or soteriological efficacy, (6) assertive hybrid warning statements, (7) ubiquitous expressives such as praise, homage, confession, and condemnation, (8) perlocutionary expressives or assertives about the joy and amazement of the audience who received the dhāraṇī under discussion, and (9) the mantradhāraṇī itself.See Davidson 2014, p. 11. By identifying these nine types of illocutionary acts across his source texts, Davidson concludes that the dhāraṇī genre is highly formalized—and to some degree formulaic—working in recognizable pragmatic patterns.Davidson 2014, p. 52.

Gyatso’s and Davidson’s characterizations of dhāraṇī are relevant to The Dhāraṇī of the Jewel Torch, in which we find frequent references to the ultimate reality of emptiness and the various codings and speech acts that Davidson outlines.
